title-group.article-title: Numerically derived evidence for late-Holocene climate change and its impact on human presence in the southwest Taurus Mountains, Turkey

author-notes.corresp: J Bakker, Department of Earth and Environmental Sciences, Katholieke Universiteit Leuven, Celestijnenlaan 200E, B-3001 Heverlee, Belgium. Email: Johan.Bakker@ees.kuleuven.be

abstract.p: A well-dated pollen diagram from Gravgaz marsh, near the archaeological site of Sagalassos (western Taurus Mountains, Turkey), provides the first detailed record of vegetation change in southwest Turkey during the last two millennia. A newly developed numerical analysis disentangles the climatic and anthropogenic influences on vegetation and reveals for the first time for southwest Turkey the timing and influence of late-Holocene climate change. Results show that sudden vegetation changes, driven by changes in moisture availability, co-occurred with well-defined European climate shifts. A trend towards dry conditions, from c. ad 640 to 940, coincides with the cold early Middle Ages in Europe. During this period, human presence in the region diminished and agricultural activity switched focus from crop cultivation to pastoralism while signs of cereal cultivation temporarily ceased. This period was followed by a return to moister conditions from ad 940 to 1280, coinciding with the ‘Medieval Climate Anomaly’. During this period there was a resurgence of human activity in the basin. Another trend towards dry conditions occurred at c. ad 1280, corresponding with the start of the ‘Little Ice Age’ in Europe and another disappearance of cereal pollen until the present day. The numerical analyses suggest that human impact around Gravgaz during the last two millennia is primarily driven by climatic changes.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Since 1995, the territory surrounding the classical city of Sagalassos has been the subject of palaeoecological research aimed at creating a better understanding of the economy and ecology of the territory through the centuries (Arndt et al., 2003; De Cupere et al., 2009; Degryse and Waelkens, 2008; Degryse et al., 2003; Kimpe et al., 2001 Poblome et al., 2001; Romanus et al., 2009; Waelkens et al., 1999, 2006). Important periods of climatic change, human impact and vegetation for the last eight millennia have been mapped in detail (Kaniewski et al., 2007a, b; Vermoere et al., 2000, 2002a, b). The focus lay on the Beyşehir Occupation Phase (BO-Phase), a period of increased anthropogenic activities which lasted from approximately 3500 to 1550 years BP (Bottema and Woldring, 1990; Bottema et al., 1986; Eastwood et al., 1998, 1999; van Zeist et al., 1975). The BO-Phase was estimated to end c. ad 650 in Gravgaz marsh, according to two separate estimations in two separate cores (Vermoere et al., 2002a, b), while palynological and archaeological records indicate a shift to pastoralism around that same time (Kaniewski et al., 2007a, b; Vanhaverbeke and Waelkens, 2003). Little is known about the period following the BO-Phase, detailed knowledge of the timing and impact of vegetation and climatic change during this period being rare for the whole of Turkey.

The ‘Medieval Climate Anomaly’ (MCA) and the ‘Little Ice Age’ (LIA) have been well-documented in literature by among others Lamb (1965), Grove (1988) Mann (1999), Wanner et al. (2008) and Bradley (2003). While the impact of the MCA varies, relatively warm conditions, and increased rainfall have been recorded for large parts of Northern Europe and Asia prior to the fourteenth century (Cronin et al., 2003; Hassan, 2007; Haug et al., 2001; Kaniewski et al., 2008; Paulsen et al., 2003; Schilman et al., 2001). Evidence shows that the occurrence of the LIA is more global and while the extent and extremes of the LIA vary, they do occur within roughly the same timeframe, between the fourteenth and the nineteenth centuries ad (Bradley and Jones, 1992; Briffa, 2000; Pfister, 1992). Records from the eastern Mediterranean (e.g. Camaron, 1993; Lamb, 1982; Pope and Van Andel, 1984) reveal a period characterized by relatively dry conditions and cooler summer temperatures characteristic for the LIA, indicating that these climatic periods could also have occurred in southwest Turkey. Unfortunately reliable records of historical climate change have been lacking until now for this important and dynamic climatic region. England et al. (2008) attempted to reveal the influence of climatic change on vegetation. However, their comparison of a pollen record from Nar Lake with the oxygen isotope record of Jones et al. (2006) only showed an anthropogenic influence.

This paper aims to reveal for the first time the timing and extent of climatic change in southwest Turkey during the last two millennia. Supported by detailed chronology and relatively high-resolution pollen data, compared with previous records from the region, pollen, non-pollen palynomorph and sedimentological data are combined with newly developed numerical methods in order to create a pollen-based climatic proxy. The pollen data illustrate how a succession of cool, dry and warm, wet periods were a driving factor behind human presence and how the natural vegetation responds to climate change and anthropogenic activity. Comparing the pollen-derived climatic data with independent climatic proxies from the Middle East and Europe, reveals how the dry and wet periods distinguished in the present study correspond with well-known European climatic periods such as the LIA and the MCA, providing new insight into past climate change, human presence and vegetation dynamics in the Near East.

sec.title: Study site
sec.p: Gravgaz marsh is located in an intramontane valley at an altitude of 1215 m above sea level (a.s.l.), 25 km southwest of Sagalassos (Figure 1) and measures approximately 800 m × 350 m. It is fed by several water sources to the west of the marsh. Water flows through the marsh via two streamlets to a karstic outflow east of the marsh. Water levels fluctuate seasonally but have dropped in recent years. Twenty years ago, water levels could be high enough to create a shallow temporary lake. The marsh has been studied previously by Six (2004) and Vermoere et al. (2000, 2002a, b) but no detailed study of vegetation and climate change during the post BO-Phase period had been attempted for the territory of Sagalassos or the wider region of southwest Turkey.

caption.p: Topographical and geological map of Gravgaz marsh

sec.p: The western Taurus Mountains, where Gravgaz is located, is considered to have an (Oro)Mediterranean climate, characterized by mild, wet winters and dry, hot summers (Paulissen et al., 1993). Recent climatic data from the nearby town of Ağlasun is displayed in Table 1.

caption.p: A summary of modern-day climatic conditions in the study area as collected by the weather station in Ağlasun (37°39’N, 30°32’E). The data present average values of data collected between 1972 and 1992 (Ağlasun Meteorology Station. Turkish State Meteorological Service, Ankara)

sec.p: Gravgaz is located within the upper unit of the Oromediterranean vegetation zone according to van Zeist et al. (1975) and at the highest vegetation zone according to Fontaine et al. (2007). Very little remains of the natural vegetation because of overgrazing. The vegetation on the hills surrounding the marsh is dominated by Quercus coccifera shrubs with Juniperus excelsa and J. oxycedrus. A pine forest is located on the hillsides southeast of the marsh. The land around the marsh is used for the cultivation of cereals and chick peas. Land not used for crop cultivation is grazed by cattle (mainly goats).

The marsh itself features a patchy vegetation pattern, dominated by Scirpus lacustris, in both wetter and drier parts. The streamlets feature Carex riparia, Typha latifolia and Sparganium erectum. The transitional zone between the fields and the marshlands is characterized by Alisma plantago/aquatica, A. Lanceolata, Butomus Umbellatus, Lythrum salicaria, Plantago major, Cirsium arvense and Agrostis gigantea. The other edges are characterized by grasses such as Lolium perenne and Hordeum murinum.

sec.title: Coring and sediment chronology
sec.p: This paper presents pollen data from the top 3 m of an 8 m core (SA06EP1) drilled in 2006, using a Dachnowsky sampler. This core is located at 30.403578°E, 37.584248°N. The ages were calibrated with the IntCal09 calibration curve (Reimer et al., 2009), using the BCal calibration program (Buck et al., 1999; http://bcal.sheffield.ac.uk). BCal uses Bayesian statistics allowing for the implementation of a priori knowledge into the age–depth model, e.g. that ages higher in the core are younger than ages lower in the core. When ages with overlapping calibrated probability distributions occur, BCal produces posterior probability distributions with non-overlapping modes, essentially wiggle-matching the ages to the calibration curve. The Bcal software also provides the option to perform an analysis of possible outliers. The material used for radiocarbon dating consisted of macroscopic charcoal fragments and terrestrial plant seeds collected using a 200 µm sieve.

sec.title: Pollen and non-pollen palynomorphs
sec.p: Forty-seven samples were isolated from the core using the standard technique of Faegri and Iversen (1989). The samples were studied under a 400× and 1250× magnification (using oil immersion) under a Leitz microscope.

Identifications of pollen types were performed using Beug (2004), Moore et al. (1991) and Reille (1992). Identifications of non-pollen palynomorphs were performed using Kuhry (1997), Pals et al. (1980), van Geel et al. (1981, 1983, 1989) and van der Wiel (1983). Pollen conservation was assessed by summing corroded, degraded, broken and crumpled pollen in a ‘deterioration assemblage’ (Cushing, 1967).

Percentage diagrams were constructed using TILIA and TGVIEW software (Grimm, 1991). Pollen data are expressed as relative frequencies (%) of the pollen sum, which includes herbaceous land plants, trees and shrubs. Poaceae were left out of the pollen sum as recent field observations supported the notion of Vermoere et al. (2002b) that grasses tend to dominate the marsh while being nearly absent on the surrounding slopes, resulting in the Poaceae signal being of local, rather than regional origin.
Pollen and non-pollen palynomorphs encountered three times or less, or which obtained a maximum percentage value of 1% were not used for the (numerical) analyses.

Pollen slide charcoal particles (50–200 µm) and larger charcoal remains (>200 µm) were counted and charcoal accumulation rates (CHAR) were computed using the CHARSTER software (http://geography.uoregon.edu/gavin/). CHAR values and deposition time were interpolated to pseudo-annual values and a moving median function with a 150 year background window was computed to exclude overrepresented background components. A threshold value was calculated using the Zero-Mean Gaussian and Gaussian Mixture Model functions in the software. Fire episodes were identified when the CHAR exceeded the background CHAR by the threshold ratio (Power et al., 2006). Each synchronous macrocharcoal and (pollen slide) microcharcoal peak above this threshold value is interpreted as a local and/or extralocal fire event. The use of accumulation rates helps distinguish between truly anomalous charcoal concentrations in the sediment and peaks in charcoal concentration that are simply the result of changing sedimentation rates.

sec.title: Numerical analysis
sec.p: Individual pollen types were grouped with a cluster analysis (CA). Data are grouped in such a way that the degree of association between two taxa is maximal when they have similar occurrences and minimal when they are dissimilar (Baxter, 1994; Kaniewski et al., 2007a). The resulting clusters are termed Pollen Derived Vegetation Patterns (PDVP). Each PDVP contains taxa that may originate from different vegetation types, but which thrive under similar environmental circumstances. The ecological significance of each PDVP can be assessed by studying the most important taxa in each PDVP and the vegetation types they are associated with. For subsequent analyses, the primary anthropogenic indicator species (as determined by Bottema and Woldring, 1990) were removed from the PDVP to which they were originally assigned. An additional CA was performed on a data set excluding cultivated plant species in order to test whether the occurrence of crop cultivation influenced the clustering of pollen types and whether the cultivated species could be removed from the data set without compromising the numerical analyses. A final CA was performed on the 14 most important non-pollen palynomorphs to generate clusters which represent local environmental conditions. The algorithm used was Paired Group and the similarity measure was Correlation.

To assess the way climate, vegetation and human presence have influenced one another in Gravgaz, it is vital to understand which of the PDVPs are directly influenced by the presence of human activities. To test this, each PDVP was cross-correlated with the primary anthropogenic indicator species (P=0.05). A linear detrended Cross-Correlation (CC) concerns the time alignment of two time series by means of the correlation coefficient and is graphically presented in a correlogram (Kaniewski et al., 2008, 2009). A strong positive correlation at Lag0 between a PDVP and the anthropogenic indicators most likely reflects an anthropogenic influence on that PDVP. If there is no correlation, then the PDVP is influenced by another (most likely environmental) factor. A negative correlation indicates that the taxa in a PDVP thrive when anthropogenic influence is absent. It should be noted that this method does not recognize human activities that do not stimulate the increase of primary and secondary anthropogenic indicator species; e.g. intense wood clearance without the development of agriculture on the cleared terrain.

Principal Component Analysis (PCA) was performed in order to reveal in what way each PDVP represents various (climatic and/or anthropogenic) environmental conditions. PCA is a linear method that can provide a two-dimensional representation of high-dimensional data. The scores of PCA-Axis1 and 2 provide numerically derived proxies that explain most of the total variance encountered in the original data set. A Detrended Correspondence Analysis (DCA) was also performed and the first axis scores of the PCA and DCA were compared to check whether the PCA results suffered from Horseshoe effect, caused by the unimodal distribution of species along gradients (Goodall, 1954). DCA is an extension of correspondence analysis (CA) designed to cope with a unimodal relationship between two sets of scores derived by CA (Hill and Gauch, 1980). If the results from the DCA and PCA do not match, then this indicates that the PCA results are affected by the Horseshoe effect and a PCA analysis is not useful in the statistical analysis of the data.
All numerical analyses were performed using the computer program PAST (http://folk.uio.no/ohammer/past/).

sec.title: Sediment lithology and core chronology
sec.p: Chronological data suggest a very fast sedimentation rate between 222 and 147 cm (Table 2, Figure 2). Pollen preservation is high, with an average of 70% of the pollen undamaged. Indeterminable pollen grain percentages are low throughout (max. 12%). Pollen concentration is high and generally stable with the exception of a single peak value at 139 cm.

caption.p: List of AMS 14C ages from core SA06EP1 (top) and the three ages from core SA06EP03 that coincide with the time interval covered in this article (bottom). All ages were calibrated using a Bayesian analysis, using the 2009 INTCAL calibration curve and the Bcal online calibration software package (Buck et al., 1999; http://bcal.sheffield.ac.uk)

tr.td: Posterior probability of sample being an outlier: 100%

fn.label: a
fn.p: Sample was too small for a seperate 13C/12C ratio and AMS analysis.

caption.p: The age–depth curve of core SA06EP1, fire episodes as identified by the CHARSTER analysis, pollen concentration, percentage indeterminable pollen and the percentage corroded/damaged pollen from core SA06EP1, and the organic matter content, CaCO3 content, bulk magnetic susceptibility and mean grain size for core SA-00-EP-3

sec.p: Figure 2 shows that sediment deposition increased briefly but drastically during the lattermost part of this zone. This sedimentation event was immediately preceded by a fire episode. The CHARSTER analysis revealed that this was by far the most intense fire recorded in the basin for the last 2000 years, reaching a CHAR of 7674 particles/cm per yr.

A detailed sediment analysis was performed by Six (2004) on a sediment core, SA00EP03, which was drilled on the same location. The lithology of this core was identical to that of core SA06EP01. The chronology of core SA00EP03 is supported by five radiocarbon dates, three of which coincide with the timeframe that the present study focuses on. The middle of these three dates was deemed an outlier when subjected to Bayesian analysis, its acceptance conflicting with a range of a priori knowledge from archaeological, palynological and geomorphological data. The radiocarbon dates of Six (2004) were performed on bulk peat samples, greatly increasing the chances of inclusion of older material in the dated sediment.

The organic matter content, calcium carbonate content, bulk magnetic susceptibility and mean grain size of core SA00EP03 were studied to determine if there are signs of reworked, disturbed sediments (Figure 2). The sediment analysis indicates that a layer containing nearly no organic material is deposited between 125 and 95 cm, coinciding with relatively high values for magnetic susceptibility and a notably increased mean grain size, caused by the presence of clay aggregates, shell fragments, unoxidized organic material, charcoal particles and iron precipitates. There are no signs of disturbed and reworked sediments, such as a distinctly increased percentage of indeterminable and corroded pollen, low organic matter content or distinctly abnormal pollen concentrations. Increased calcium carbonate content of the sediment may indicate increased erosion of the calcium-rich sediments on the hillside. However, Six (2004) indicates that here the calcium carbonate mostly precipitates from groundwater.
Six (2004) reports that sedimentation rates in Gravgaz dropped after the BO Phase and remained relatively stable until the present, notwithstanding occasional short-term events.

sec.title: Numerical analysis of pollen data
sec.p: Based on the CA results, the pollen data were subdivided into six PDVPs. Removing the cultivated species did not alter the clustering of pollen types by the CA. The most abundant and/or ecologically indicative plant species in each PDVP and the vegetation types to which they belong were studied to acquire an idea of the environmental conditions represented by each PDVP. The CA performed on the non-pollen palynomorphs resulted in a subdivision into five groups representing specific local circumstances (Figure 3).

caption.p: The Cluster Analysis tree diagrams. The top diagram displays the six different pollen-derived vegetation patterns. The bottom diagram displays the five different groups of non-pollen palynomorphs, each group indicating a specific set of local conditions. The vegetation types associated with the most important pollen taxa in each PDVP are based on van Zeist et al. (1975), Bottema and Woldring (1990), Fontaine et al. (2007) and Kaniewski et al. (2007a)

sec.p: The CCs reveal that only PDVP D is positively correlated with the cultivated plant species. The CA added all cultivated species to this PDVP and it contains all secondary anthropogenic indicators. There is a strong (not significant) negative correlation between PDVP A, dominated by Pinus, and cultivated species, indicating how pine forests apparently increase when anthropogenic pressure diminishes. None of the other PDVPs, regardless of the ecological preferences of their dominant plant taxa show any correlation, suggesting that PCA-Axis 1 and 2 are not primarily controlled by the presence/absence of crop cultivation but were directly or indirectly driven by external forces (e.g. climate).

PCA-axis scores were identical to those of the DCA, indicating that the horseshoe effect does not occur. The PCA scatter plot and the loadings of the different pollen-derived vegetation types are detailed in Figure 4. PCA axes 1 (50.3% of total variance) and 2 (22.8% of total variance) account for 73.1% of the cumulative variance. The PCA-axis 1 loadings assign positive scores to PDVP A (+0.87) and F (+0.06) and negative scores to PDVP B (−0.33), D (−0.30), E (−0.14) the cultivated species (−0.11) and PDVP C (−0.04). The PCA-axis 2 loadings assign positive scores to PDVP B (+0.85) and A (+0.15) and negative scores to PDVP D (−0.36), C (−0.24), the cultivated species (−0.21), PDVP E (−0.11) and F (−0.08). The PCA-axis 1 and PCA-axis 2 scores, and local vegetation and non-pollen palynomorphs dynamics during the last 2000 years are presented in Figure 5.

caption.p: Top: Correlograms of the cultivated species versus the PDVP’s. The vertical axes show the correlation coefficients. The significance level is P=0.05. The cross-correlations were performed on pollen percentage data as well as pollen count data. In both cases the results were similar. The correlogram highlighted in grey displays the positive correlation between the cultivated species and PDVP D, containing secondary anthropogenic indicators. Bottom: Principal components analysis of the samples with biplot function. PCA axes 1 (53.6% of total variance) and 2 (25.4% of total variance) account for 79% of the cumulative variance

Left: PDVP percentage values, PCA-axis 1 and PCA-axis 2 scores for the core SA06EP1 for all samples dated from ad 0 to 2000. The grey lines in the PCA-axis 1 and 2 graphs show the three-point moving averages for the axis scores. The curve named ‘Cultivated species’ contains the primary anthropogenic indicator species (as determined by Bottema and Woldring, 1990) as a cumulative percentage diagram featuring cereal pollen (light grey) and cultivated trees (dark grey). Right: local wetland plant taxa and non-pollen palynomorphs groups for all samples dated from ad 0 to 2000. The graph displays the values of the local plant taxa and non-pollen as percentages of the total pollen sum. As these palynomorphs are not included in the pollen sum, their percentage values may exceed 100%. The diagram also displays the presence of fire events as identified by CHARSTER along a timescale

sec.p: The loadings for PCA-axis 1 order the different PDVPs according to landscape openness, based on the most important vegetation types represented by each PDVP. PDVP A receives the highest positive loading and contains Pinus as its most important component. PDVP B receives the highest negative loading and contains Asteraceae cichorioideae as its dominant pollen type, which in combination with Caryophyllaceae, may indicate open mountain steppe. Betula may occur as a remnant of mountain forests, its pollen signal no longer drowned out by copious pollen production of Pinus. Cistus and Carpinus pollen types indicate Maquis type vegetation.

The loadings of the PDVPs along PCA-axis 2 indicate relative moisture availability. Taxa indicative of a moist environment (e.g. Platanus Populus, Celtis, Salix, Ulmus) are encompassed in the PDVPs D and E. Juniperus is the most important pollen type in PDVP C. The humid-dependent J. excelsa is an important species above 1200 m (a.s.l.). PDVP F contains only Abies, which requires a high degree of humidity (Fontaine et al., 2007). PDVP A received a positive loading and contains Pinus as its dominant pollen type. Pinus nigra, an important component of mountain pine forests in the region, is drought-tolerant and known to occur in drier environments in Turkey. The light-/heat-demanding Pinus brutia becomes scarce above 1200 m a.s.l. and does not occur above 1400 m a.s.l. but may contribute to the regional pollen signal. PDVP B, indicative of dry steppe and maquis vegetation, is given the highest positive loading. It seems that, while open and more densely forested landscapes are indicated by PDVPs with positive as well as negative loadings, the PDVPs with high positive loadings are indicative of moister landscapes than those with lower loadings along the second PCA-Axis.

sec.title: Landscape and environmental development
sec.p: Given the notion that PCA-axis 2 scores indicate relative moisture availability, five distinct periods, characterized by relatively dry and relatively wet environmental conditions can be identified. Short-term fluctuations in the percentage values and PCA scores may be caused by the yearly variations in pollen production found in many deciduous tree species. The amount of pollen produced is strongly dependent on the weather during the flowering season and varies from year to year. Some peak values may be caused by isolated events such as a fire. The use of a single numerically derived proxy, rather than pollen types, helps neutralize the obscuring influence of such fluctuations. While the following section will also describe some of the more distinct peak values in PCA scores and PDVP percentage values, the interpretation of the data and the resulting conclusions are based only on the main, long-term trends, which are more likely a result of changes that occur in the wider region. The start and end ages of these zones are extrapolations based on the available radiocarbon dates for this record and their accuracy is therefore less than absolute.

sec.title: Roman Wet Period (until 246 cm, until c. ad 650)
sec.p: This period is characterized by strong negative scores for both PCA axes and generally high values for cultivated plant species as well as PDVP D, containing secondary anthropogenic indicators. Locally this zone is characterized by relatively high values for Poaceae and Cyperaceae. The occurrence of a peat layer may be may indicate a lowering of the water level, although there are no indications of local dryness in the non-pollen and CaCO3 data. An ad 250 peak in Asteraceae/PCA-axis 2 scores corresponds with high percentages of damaged and indeterminable pollen grains and a peak value for non-pollen group 5, indicating dry local circumstances and the presence of dung.

sec.title: Early Medieval Dry Period (246–156 cm, c. ad 650–940)
sec.p: PCA-axis 1 values fluctuate throughout this zone. PCA-axis 2 scores shift to predominantly positive scores at the start of this zone, coinciding with a drop in cultivated trees and the disappearance of Olea and cereals. Above 217 cm, cereals return, but at lower percentages than before. Despite small deviations, this zone is characterized by high values for PDVP B. Locally this zone is characterized by low values for Poaceae and Cyperaceae compared with the preceding zone. Aquatic non-pollen types remain present, indicating that the sample site remained wet.

The 222–147 cm sedimentation event was immediately preceded by a fire episode. The CHARSTER analysis revealed that this was the most intense fire recorded in the basin for the last 2000 years, reaching a CHAR of 7674 particles/cm per yr. Elevated values for bulk magnetic susceptibility and CaCO3 content indicate moist local conditions on the sample site during a very brief period.

sec.title: Medieval Wet Period (156–116 cm, c. ad 940–1280)
sec.p: This zone is characterized by a positive trend in PCA-axis 1 and negative values for PCA-axis 2. High PCA-axis 1 scores are driven by high percentages for PDVP A and F. PDVP C (indicating Juniper shrub and woodlands) decreases throughout this zone. Negative scores for PCA-axis 2 are driven by higher percentages for PDVP C and D and a resurgence of cultivated species. Fire events occur at 140 and 130 cm depth. Calcium carbonates in the basin originate from precipitation of source and groundwater and not from erosion of the limestone mountains (Six, 2004). High CaCO3 values in this zone therefore indicate an increase in precipitation of groundwater. The end of this zone is characterized by high values of magnetic susceptibility, low percentages of organic matter and increased mean grain size. The large coarse material found in this portion of the core consists primarily of clay aggregates, together with shell fragments, unoxidized organic material, charcoal particles and iron precipitates.

sec.title: Post Medieval Dry Period (116–57 cm, c. ad 1280–1710)
sec.p: PCA-axis 1 shows a negative trend while PCA-axis 2 scores are generally higher than within the preceding zone and predominantly positive. This zone coincides with a second period without cereal cultivation and is characterized by high PDVP B values and a strong positive trend for PDVP C. Locally this zone shows increased values for all non-pollen palynomorphs.

sec.title: Post Medieval Wet Period (57–0 cm, c. ad 1710–present)
sec.p: The negative trend in PCA-Axis 1 is reversed with scores continuously increasing, only dropping in the uppermost pollen samples. The positive trend is mostly driven by high values for PDVP C. PCA-axis 2 scores are predominantly negative and generally marked by high values for PDVP C.
Locally this zone is characterized by increasing percentage values for all non-pollen groups but is dominated by high values of Glomus, indicating soil disturbance and erosion.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The ecological preferences of the dominant species in each PDVP indicate that PCA-axis 2 scores are an indication of moisture availability. The following section describes the observed vegetation changes in the light of this assumption and will compare the timing and apparent nature of the natural environment (relatively dry or relatively wet) to a series of independent climatic proxies from the Middle East and northwest Europe.

When occurring in dry and degraded vegetation, pastoralism may not be indicated by secondary anthropogenic indicators. In such circumstances, grazing may be detected by increased values of coprophilous non-pollen palynomorphs and the development of a degraded Quercus coccifera/Juniperus oxcycedrus-dominated woodland (Figure 7). Q. coccifera is included in the PDVP D, with the primary and secondary anthropogenic indicators, indicating that Q. coccifera is an indicator of grazing pressure.

Asteraceae percentages occasionally show peaks, reaching up to 40%. These peaks do not coincide with higher percentages of damaged pollen or indications of abnormal sediment disposition. The notion that these values are caused by differential pollen preservation is rejected on these grounds.

High Asteraceae percentages occur frequently in cores from Turkey and occur in cores from Ağlasun, near Sagalassos (Vermoere, 2004). According to Bottema and Woldring (1984, 1990), heating effects in the summer may cause upward wind flows which transport and concentrate Asteraceae pollen, precipitating them in relatively cool locations such as lakes and valleys. This process would require a relatively open landscape and low levels of cloud cover and precipitation. High levels of Asteraceae can therefore be a sign of dry climatic conditions in an open landscape. Earlier records from Gravgaz have not recorded any such peaks as their lower resolution may have missed them. The sample site of the current core is located in the middle of the swamp, which is a more ideal place for the deposition of Asteraceae pollen compared with previously studied sample sites (Six, 2004; Vermoere, 2004; Vermoere et al., 2000, 2002a, b), nearer to the edge of the basin.

sec.title: Roman Wet Period (until ad 650)
sec.p: The regional vegetation indicates high moisture availability and featured anthropogenic meadow-steppe, riparian woodlands and cereal cultivation and arboriculture, corresponding with the latest part of the BO Phase. The amount of pine forests increased throughout this period. The ad 250 dry event is too short to be considered a sign of climate change or even to be considered anything but a random local phenomenon, were it not for the fact that it coincides with a short dry event observed for the Bereket Basin by Kaniewski et al. (2007a, b). Short-term a similar dry event is also recorded for the Dead Sea (Neumann et al., 2007) and the northeastern Arabian Sea (von Rad et al., 1999).

sec.title: Early Medieval Dry Period (c. ad 640–940)
sec.p: The start of this period is characterized by a decrease in arboriculture and the disappearance of cereals and Olea pollen-type from the pollen record, coinciding with an abrupt change to predominantly dry environmental conditions as the anthropogenic meadow-steppe is replaced by a dry and open herbaceous steppe. The gradual increase of Pinus may indicate natural reforestation. The open landscape may be the result of overgrazing, preventing pine forests from recovering. An increase in pastoral activities is also suggested by finds of animal bones dating from this period (de Cupere, 1998). As grazing intensifies, evergreen oak scrublands may become too degraded to produce much pollen).

This sedimentation event at the end of this period corresponds with the intense fire episode at c. ad 910. After an especially intense fire on or near a sample site, the vegetation holding the sediment together will be destroyed, often resulting in an increased sediment deposition rate (Frechette and Meyer, 2009; Moody and Martin, 2001). The c. ad 910 fire event is also immediately followed by a layer of sediments containing detritic matter and having a slightly elevated mean grain size. Both characteristics indicate this layer was deposited relatively fast. The chronological data indicate that a similar layer, occurring between 165 and 129 cm, was deposited far less rapidly. Signs of the presence of reworked or disturbed sediments remain absent.

A strong link between human presence and fire activity has also been observed for the nearby Bereket basin (Kaniewski et al., 2008), supporting the notion that fire episodes in Gravgaz can be interpreted as a sign of increased human presence.

Vermoere et al. (2002a, b) have suggested a switch from crop cultivation to pastoralism after the BO-Phase in Gravgaz and attributed this to a series of natural disasters that diminished the population and the destructive sixth-century earthquake that finally destroyed Sagalassos (Waelkens et al., 2000). Leroy et al. (2010) showed a marked decrease in human presence and a switch to pastoralism following an earthquake. However, in Gravgaz, the switch directly coincides with the onset of a widespread, lengthy period of drought, implying that climate played a more important role in driving changes in human occupation.

Similar periods of drought have been observed across the eastern Mediterranean and the Middle East. A switch from agriculture to pastoralism during the seventh century ad is also encountered at the Dead Sea (Leroy, 2010) where it coincides with the Muslim invasion as well as an aridification of the region as indicated by a drop in the lake level (Enzel et al., 2003; Neumann et al., 2010). The occurrence of a dry period is noted by Kaniewski et al. (2010) for the coastal region of Syria between c. ad 850 and c. 1000 and at Nar lake, Turkey, between the ninth and the eleventh centuries ad (Jones et al., 2006). A general trend towards dryer conditions is observed for the Ashdod coast (Schillman et al., 2001, 2002) (Figure 6) and Soreq Cave (Bar-Matthews et al., 1999; Schillman et al., 2002). A decrease in precipitation is indicated by decreased fluvial inputs in the Arabian Sea from the fifth to the tenth centuries ad (Lückge et al., 2001; von Rad et al., 1999) and a decrease in the Nile runoffs since the eighth century ad (Jiang et al., 2002). High δ18O values indicate drier conditions for the northern Red Sea between the seventh and the eleventh centuries ad (Lamy et al., 2006). δ14C values were generally higher than during the BO-Phase, suggesting a decreased solar irradiance (Reimer et al., 2004). Historical data show that winters became colder and the Bosporus frequently froze after the start of the eighth century ad (Yavuz et al., 2007). The assumed start and end dates of these climatic periods do not always coincide, but their occurrences do overlap and differences in timing may be a result of the limitations of the chronology available for some of these records. Nevertheless, drier conditions during the seventh to eleventh centuries ad were widespread in the eastern Mediterranean. The current study shows that SW Turkey was no exception. Several European records also indicate that temperatures were lower during early Medieval times than during the periods preceding and succeeding this ‘Early Middle Ages Cold Period’ (Castagnoli et al., 2002; Desprat et al., 2003; Niggemann et al., 2003).

caption.p: A comparison of the occurrence of humid and dry trends from ad 0 to 2000 in climate records from the Middle East (Schilman et al., 2001, 2002), the Northern Atlantic (Bond et al., 2001), Asia (Gupta et al., 2003) and the atmospheric radiocarbon record (Reimer et al., 2004) with the Gravgaz PCA-axis 2 scores. The grey line in the PCA-axis 2 graph indicates the three-point moving average

sec.title: Medieval Wet Period (c. ad 940–1280)
sec.p: Throughout this period, moisture availability was relatively high locally and regionally. The onset of this period is marked by continued fire activity, although charcoal accumulation rates were lower than during the c. ad 910 fire episode and evidence for increased sedimentation is lacking. These fire events and increases in anthropogenic indicators are indications of a renewed anthropogenic interest in the valley as moisture availability increased.

High values for magnetic susceptibility, encountered at the end of this period, are attributed to a concentration of magnetic materials in a wet environment, possibly deposited by a small streamlet that briefly flowed across the drill site on its way from the springs to the karstic outflow of the basin (Six, 2004). This notion is supported by the increased mean grain size, the nature of the fragments indicating an aquatic environment.

Wetter conditions between the eleventh and fourteenth centuries ad occur throughout the Mediterranean and the Middle East. The δ18O records from Soreq cave and the Ashdod coast show a trend towards wetter conditions since the early twelfth century ad. However, in both records the wettest period occurs several centuries later than in Gravgaz (Bar-Matthews et al., 1999; Schillman et al., 2001, 2002) (Figure 6).

In coastal Syria (Kaniewski et al., 2010) and the northern Red Sea (Lamy et al., 2006) a wet trend commences at the beginning of the eleventh century ad while the Dead Sea water level rose strongly between the eleventh and thirteenth centuries ad (Enzel et al., 2003). At Nar Lake (England et al., 2008; Jones et al., 2006), a phase characterized by lower summer evaporation and increased winter rainfall occurred between the eleventh and fourteenth centuries ad. Gupta et al. (2003) note a strong Asian SW Monsoon from the tenth to the thirteenth centuries ad (Figure 6) and fluvial inputs in the Arabian Sea off Pakistan increase from c. ad 950 to 1100 and remain relatively high until the beginning of the thirteenth century ad (Lückge et al., 2001; von Rad et al., 1999). The Medieval Wet Period recorded in Gravgaz coincides with low percentages of North-Atlantic Hematite-stained grains recorded during the European MCA (Bond et al., 2001) (Figure 6).

Although no conclusive evidence exists of a single temporally coherent warm period that spanned the same time interval over a wide area (Hughes and Diaz, 1994), the eastern Mediterranean and Middle East have been subjected to more humid/warm conditions roughly between the tenth and fourteenth centuries ad. This study indicates that the climate in southwest Turkey followed the wet trend encountered during the height of the MCA in Asia and Europe.

sec.title: The Post Medieval Dry Period (c. ad 1280–1710)
sec.p: Conditions remained relatively dry throughout this period. Signs of human presence are relatively scarce while cereal cultivation in the region stops. Elevated percentages of Asteraceae during this period may indicate the grazing/herding of cattle and selective pollen transportation in a dry and open environment. Landscape openness around the marsh fluctuates but a general trend can be observed where the amount of forest decreases as the region becomes increasingly covered by Juniperus scrubland.

A similar trend is found in records from the Soreq cave and the Ashdod coast (Bar-Matthews et al., 1999; Schillman et al., 2001, 2002). The Red Sea planktonic δ18O record (Lamy et al., 2006) shows a dry trend from c. ad 1200 to 1550. Records from Nar Lake (England et al., 2008; Jones et al., 2006) and the Dead Sea (Neumann et al., 2010) show a shift towards dryer conditions at c. ad 1400. The onset of dry conditions observed in Gravgaz is also corresponds with the perceived start of the ‘Little Ice Age’ in Europe and the North Atlantic (Grove, 1988, 2001), the onset of a cool trend in the hematite-stained grains data of Bond et al. (2001) and an increase in atmospheric 14C levels (Reimer et al., 2004).

sec.title: Post Medieval Wet Period (c. ad 1710–present)
sec.p: The decrease of Pinus forest during this period may be the result of increased timber export from the nearby port city of Antalya and the consequent deforestation that took place in the Taurus Mountains during the nineteenth century ad (de Planhol 1958; Vanhaverbeke and Waelkens, 2003). Logging activities may have caused the disturbance of the sediment, and increased erosion, which may be indicated by a strong increase in Glomus (Figures 5 and 7, NP1). The high abundance of juniper woodland indicates a relatively wet environment as a dry environment would have caused the establishment of dryland steppe.

caption.p: Pollen percentage diagram, showing the most important local and regional pollen taxa and non-pollen palynomorphs. Selected curves show a 4× exaggeration in black

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The newly developed numerical analyses performed on the pollen data reveal five relatively humid or dry periods, their start and end dates corresponding with well-known, large-scale periods of climate change, recording for the first time the occurrence and timing of the MCA and (the start of) the LIA in southwest Turkey. The data provide new insights concerning past climate change and its influence on human occupation and vegetation dynamics in the Near East.

The BO-Phase, characterized by intensive arboriculture, ends around c. ad 650 and is followed by a relatively dry period, coinciding with cold and dry climatic periods recorded for the Mediterranean and Europe. Anthropogenic activity decreased and switched from crop cultivation to pastoral activities. The resulting open, degraded landscape became increasingly covered with pine forests. A wetter phase occurred around c. ad 940–1280, coinciding with the height of the MCA. Fire events and increased amounts of anthropogenic indicators indicate resurgence in human activity. From c. ad 1280, coinciding with the start of the European LIA and a decrease in solar irradiance, a drier phase occurs. The most recent period is characterized by abundant juniper woodlands, perhaps caused by logging activities in the region during the nineteenth century. The current landscape is a result of an intensification of agriculture since the mid-twentieth century. Generally, the post BO-Phase vegetation was characterized by meadow-steppe, riparian woodlands and abundant Juniperus during periods with relatively high moisture availability. Drier periods were characterized by dryland steppe and maquis type vegetation while pine forests became abundant when grazing pressure was low.
Work to obtain data from other locations in the region in order to properly distinguish between local and regional environmental phenomena in the territory, is ongoing.

ack.p: We would like to thank the following people for their help: Prof. Dr Etienne Paulissen for his work in the field and his ideas and thoughts on the subject. Bas van Geel, Prof. Dr Henry Hooghiemstra, Prof. Dr Ir Bart Muys for sharing their ideas and thoughts on this subject, Antonio Trabucco for his help collecting the modern-day climatic data, Annemarie Philip for her help and expertise in preparing pollen samples and Dr Elena Marinova for her help in identifying pollen types. The Sagalassos Archaeological Research Project is thanked for providing administrative and logistical support.

M. Waelkens is one of the people who received a ‘Methusalem grant’ from the Flemish Ministry for Science Policy.
